__data__.text: Barcelona, the capital of Catalonia, is located in northeastern Spain on the Mediterranean coast, specifically between 41°16'-41°30' N latitude and 1°54'-2°18' E longitude. The city spans an area of 102.16 km², primarily a 11 km by 6 km plain surrounded by the sea, Collserola mountain range (with Tibidabo peak at 516.2 m), and Montjuïc mountain (184.8 m) that separates the city from the Llobregat delta.

Barcelona, located in northeastern Spain, is situated on a coastal plain surrounded by the Montjuïc mountain (184.8 m) and the Collserola mountain range, which includes several parallel hills such as La Peira, La Rovira, El Carmel, Creueta del Coll, El Putget, and Monterols. The plain, which is not flat but has undulations due to historical torrents, has a general slope ascending towards the Collserola mountain range, with an elevation change of approximately 260 m. The area's geology consists of slate, granitic formations, clays, and limestones. Two primary fault lines are present, one between the Collserola mountain range and the nearby hills, and another separating Montjuïc from the coast.

Barcelona's terrain is characterized by slate, granitic formations, clays, and limestones. Its coastal marshes and lagoons have been replaced by advancing sediments since the 6th century BC, extending the coastline by approximately 5 km. The area was once crisscrossed by numerous torrents, grouped into three sectors: Horta stream in the east, Blanca stream and Gornal torrent in the west, and several streams from Tibidabo's southern slope in the center. The city has a Mediterranean climate with mild winters due to its terrain's protection from northern winds, and temperatures typically range between 9.5 °C and 24.3 °C.

Barcelona's climate is Mediterranean with mild winters and temperatures between 9.5 °C and 24.3 °C, and low annual rainfall of around 600 mm. Historically, water supply was ensured through wells, canals, and irrigation ditches. The area was once home to rainfed and irrigated agriculture, primarily vineyards and cereals, but now it is almost entirely urbanized. Barcelona is the most significant urban center in Catalonia, serving as the regional and provincial capital, as well as the seat of the autonomous government, parliament, and various other institutions. It boasts a port, airport, and extensive transportation networks. Vegetation in the area consists mainly of pines and evergreen oaks, with undergrowth of heather, laurestine, arbutus, and climbing plants.

Barcelona is the seat of several significant institutions, including the autonomous government, parliament, provincial deputation, archbishopric, and IV Military Region. It has a port, airport, and extensive transportation networks. In 2015, it was the second most populous city in Spain and the eleventh in the European Union. Barcelona is divided into 10 districts and 73 neighborhoods, one of which is Ciutat Vella, the historic core of the city that has seen immigration from other parts of Spain and other countries. This district has the oldest and lowest socioeconomic level population, but gentrification has begun due to urban development plans.

Barcelona's Ciutat Vella district is the city's oldest and lowest socioeconomic area, but gentrification has started due to urban development plans, and it boasts significant monuments and institutions. The Eixample district emerged from the city's expansion, initially housing wealthy families, but now has a stabilized middle-class population.

The Eixample district, once home to affluent families, has a stabilized middle-class population today and is a significant tourist attraction due to its modernist architectural works, drawing commercial brands and visitors. Sants-Montjuïc, the largest district, comprises the old town of Sants and Montjuïc mountain, has a lower population density, a higher percentage of green spaces, and a greater proportion of foreign residents than other districts. Horta-Guinardó, once an agricultural area, developed urban and industrial features in the early 19th century and experienced real estate speculation, leading to a densely populated district with older, lower-middle class residents and above-average education levels. Nou Barris, the most recently formed district, is on land originally part of Sant Andreu de Palomar and has a younger demographic and lower population density. Sant Andreu, now a district, was once a separate municipality with an agricultural and milling focus until the mid-19th century when industries moved in. In the mid-20th century, it saw a significant wave of immigration, resulting in working-class residents with low purchasing power living in areas like Bon Pastor and Baró de Viver. This district has faced infrastructure and service gaps, but they have improved in recent times.

In the mid-1900s, Sant Andreu and Sant Martí experienced significant immigration, with working-class residents settling in areas like Bon Pastor, Baró de Viver, and Sant Martí de Provençals. These districts were initially agricultural and milling areas but underwent industrialization during the Industrial Revolution. Recently, they have shifted towards new technology-based economic activities. Sant Andreu has faced infrastructure and service gaps but has seen improvement, while Sant Martí experienced revitalization due to commercial activities and the 1992 Olympic Games' impact on its waterfront and Olympic Village. The administrative division of both districts has changed over time.

The 1992 Olympic Games led to the renovation of Sant Martí's waterfront, which hosted the Olympic Village. The district's historical administrative division has experienced changes since its initial division into four quarters in 1389 – Framenors, Pi, Mar, and Sant Pere. This division, based on a grid with Plaça del Blat as the center, reflected social differences: Framenors was aristocratic, Pi was residential and civil service, Sant Pere was industrial and commercial, and Mar was popular and religious, housing many convents and monasteries.

The division of Sant Martí has undergone several changes since its initial division into four quarters in 1389. A fifth quarter, Raval, was added in the 15th century, and in 1769, it was reformed into five quarters, each with eight neighborhoods. The 19th century saw numerous divisions, many for political reasons, including the divisions in 1837 into four districts and in 1878 into ten districts, which was implemented after the demolition of the city walls.

The division of Sant Martí has been altered multiple times since its original division into four quarters in 1389. A Raval quarter was added in the 15th century, and it was later reformed into five quarters with eight neighborhoods in 1769. In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, several neighboring municipalities were incorporated into the city, leading to another administrative reorganization with ten districts. These districts included I-Barceloneta and Pueblo Nuevo, II-San Pedro, III-Lonja and Audiencia, IV-Concepción, V-Atarazanas and Hospital, VI-Universidad, VII-Sans, Las Corts and Hostafranchs, VIII-Gracia and San Gervasio, IX-Horta and Sant Andreu de Palomar, X-Sant Martí de Provençals. In 1933, the districts were reorganized again into ten, including I-Barceloneta, II-Poble Sec and Montjuïc, and III-Sarrià.

In 1933, the number of districts in Barcelona increased to ten, with X-Sant Martí de Provençals being one of them. Later, in 1949, two more districts were added, making the total twelve. However, the current division into ten districts was not approved until 1984, with the goal of decentralizing the City Council and preserving the historical and morphological identity of each district while ensuring functional delimitation and access to a wide range of services for residents.

In 1933, Barcelona's districts expanded to ten, and two more were added in 1949, but the current division into ten districts was only officially approved in 1984. This reform aimed to preserve the historical and morphological identity of each district, create practical and functional boundaries, and ensure access to various services for residents. The 2006 reform then focused on establishing the neighborhoods within each district to enhance the distribution of facilities and proximity services. Some areas, like Pedralbes, Vallcarca, El Guinardó, and Nou Barris, experienced changes in their historical belonging during these reforms.

In 1933 and 1949, Barcelona's districts expanded, and the current division into ten districts was officially approved in 1984 to preserve historical and morphological identities and improve access to services. The 2006 reform focused on creating 73 neighborhoods based on historical, cultural, and social criteria, causing controversy due to the fragmentation of some historical neighborhoods and unfulfilled aspirations of others. Barcelona's history traces back to its founding as Barcino by Roman colonizers in the first century BC, initially as a small walled city on Mons Taber (current Plaça de Sant Jaume).

The Roman period of Barcelona, starting from its foundation as Barcino in the first century BC, experienced its peak during the second century with a population of around 3500-5000 inhabitants. The city was built on a small promontory near the coast due to its natural harbor, although this later posed challenges due to alluvium from torrents and sand sedimentation. The city's center, the forum, was the hub of public life and business, situated at the intersection of the cardus maximus and decumanus maximus (main streets), approximately in the middle of the walled area.

During the Roman era of Barcelona, known as Barcino, the city flourished in the second century with a population of 3500-5000 inhabitants. The city, built near the coast for its natural harbor, featured an orthogonal layout with square/rectangular blocks along a grid pattern, determined by two main axes. This design served as a model for Ildefonso Cerdá's Plan de Eixample in 1859. The Romans were skilled in architecture and civil engineering, constructing roads, bridges, aqueducts, and an urban plan with basic services and a rational layout. The city was enclosed by a 1.5 km perimeter wall, which was reinforced and expanded in the 4th century due to invasions by Franks and Alemanni.

During the Roman era in Barcelona, known as Barcino, the city's growth led to the reinforcement of its walls due to invasions by Franks and Alemanni in the 250s. In the 4th century, the city built a new wall on the foundations of the first, which featured a double wall of 2 meters with a stone and mortar-filled space in between. This wall had approximately 74 towers, the majority being rectangular, standing at around 18 meters high. Additionally, remnants of Roman urban elements include a necropolis found in Plaça de la Vila de Madrid, containing over 70 tombs from the second and third centuries, discovered in 1954.

During the Roman era in Barcelona, called Barcino, the city's expansion required reinforced walls to protect against invasions, including the construction of a new wall in the 4th century with towers and a double wall filled with stone and mortar. Remnants of Roman urban elements, such as a necropolis and aqueducts, can still be found. After the fall of the Roman Empire, the city was conquered by various civilizations, including the Visigoths and Arabs, and was part of the Carolingian Empire. The city served as a military stronghold, leading to its growth and eventual status as the capital of the territory. During this time, the countryside was colonized, and suburbs began to appear, marking the beginning of suburbanization, all within a feudal structure (Medieval period).

During the Roman period and throughout the Middle Ages, Barcelona experienced growth and development, starting with the construction of reinforced walls and towers for protection and later becoming a county within the Carolingian Empire. After being conquered by various civilizations, the city became an essential maritime and commercial hub of the Mediterranean Sea as part of the Crown of Aragon and the Principality of Catalonia. Suburbanization occurred, and the city expanded from its original core (the Gothic Quarter) to include the Raval district. The growth was driven by Barcelona's roles as a political, religious, and trade center, and as a node for intricate social and institutional relationships. The city's population reached approximately 25,000 inhabitants in the 14th century. Barcelona's development can be traced back to its reconstruction after the destruction by Almanzor in 985, building upon the existing Roman infrastructure.

During the Roman and medieval periods, Barcelona evolved as a center of political and religious power, trade, and craft production, forming a unique identity and hinterland. This growth led to the establishment of the Council of One Hundred in 1265 to manage the city's administration, which included supplying food and water, maintaining roads, census, territorial demarcation, and creating urban building patterns. The Consuetuds de Santacilia, introduced by James I, defined the first urban layouts. Additionally, Barcelona hosted a Jewish quarter, the Call, situated near the current streets of Ferran, Banys Nous, Palla, and Bisbe.

The Jewish quarter, or Call, of Barcelona was established in 692 and existed until its destruction in 1391 due to xenophobic violence. It was walled off from the rest of the city and contained two synagogues, bathhouses, schools, and hospitals. The area surrounding Barcelona, known as the "hort i vinyet de Barcelona," was primarily used for agriculture, with a focus on producing fruits, vegetables, and wine for the city. This area was located between the streams of Horta and Sants and the Collserola mountain range, Puig Aguilar, and Coll de Codines, extending to the sea.

The Jewish Quarter in Barcelona was established in 692 and lasted until its destruction in 1391, and the area surrounding Barcelona, known as "hort i vinyet de Barcelona," was used for agriculture. This agricultural development was strengthened in the mid-10th century by the construction of two canals that directed the waters of the Llobregat and Besòs rivers towards the city. These canals, Rec Comtal or Regomir and the Strata Francisca, improved the city's connection to the center of the Carolingian Empire. After the threat of Muslim attacks ended, the first settlements outside the city walls were built.

In the post-Muslim attack period, several new population centers (vila nova) emerged, typically forming around churches and monasteries. Examples include the port-oriented neighborhood near Santa Maria del Mar church, the agrarian-focused area around Sant Cugat del Rec, the Sant Pere neighborhood associated with Sant Pere de les Puelles, the church-centered El Pi neighborhood, the Santa Anna neighborhood adjacent to its similarly-named church, the Arcs neighborhood near Portal del Bisbe, and the Mercadal neighborhood built around Portal Major market.

After the Muslim attacks, the Raval neighborhood came into existence as a suburban area with orchards and various religious structures, such as the monastery of Sant Pau del Camp (914), the church of Sant Antoni Abat (1157), the convent of the Carmelites Calçats (1292), the priory of Nazareth (1342), and the monastery of Montalegre (1362). As new neighborhoods like Raval emerged, the city expanded its walls in 1260, constructing a new section from Sant Pere de les Puelles to the Drassanes, facing the sea. This extension, 5100 m long and 1.5 km² wide, featured eighty towers and eight gates, including significant sites like Portal de l'Àngel, Portaferrissa, and La Boqueria.

The expanded city walls of 1260 added 80 towers and 8 new gates, including significant sites like Portal de l'Àngel, Portaferrissa, and La Boqueria. Surrounding fortifications were constructed for defense, such as the castle of the Port, Montjuïc; those of Martorell and Castellví de Rosanes at the Llobregat river entrance; Eramprunyà and Castelldefels in the Llobregat delta; and Montcada at the Besòs river entrance. The medieval urban fabric was divided into areas of influence by the aristocracy, institutional power, the bishopric, religious orders, guilds, and trade associations. The street network was irregular, and squares were simply widened streets or plots of land from demolished houses, often used for storage.

The street layout in the expanded city was irregular, with squares being widened streets or land from demolished houses used for storage purposes, often holding items like wheat, wool, or coal. Houses were typically "artisan-type," consisting of a workshop on the first floor and one or two floors for living, sized around 4 meters wide and 10-12 meters deep, sometimes accompanied by a small vegetable garden. Larger structures included churches, palaces, and a few institutional buildings, such as the Casa de la Ciutat and Palau de la Generalitat de Catalunya, as well as hospitals and other significant buildings like the Llotja and Drassanes. In 1209, one of the earliest examples of private urban planning occurred when Peter II granted Guillem Ramon de Montcada permission to create Montcada street, a wide and straight road lined with grand residences from the Bòria to the sea.

During the expansion of the city, there were a few urban planning processes, including the creation of Montcada street in 1209 and the Plaça Nova in 1355. The latter was formed by demolishing several houses and repurposing the Bishop's orchard, next to the Episcopal Palace and near the cathedral. In the 14th and 15th centuries, the city underwent continuous growth, leading to the construction of the Raval wall, which expanded the walled enclosure to 218 ha and 6 km perimeter. Notable features of this extension include the current ring roads of Sant Pau, Sant Antoni, Universitat, and Sant Pere, as well as the long avenue, La Rambla, previously occupied by religious institutions. Currently, only the Portal de Santa Madrona remains preserved.

The Raval wall expansion in the 14th and 15th centuries led to the creation of La Rambla, initially filled with religious institutions and later transformed into a popular strolling area by 1444. Only Portal de Santa Madrona remains preserved today. During the Middle Ages, a road network emerged, connecting Barcelona to nearby suburbs, villages, and points of interest, such as farms, mills, quarries, churches, and fountains. This development took place on the Barcelona plain and continued into the Early Modern Age.

During the Early Modern Age, Barcelona and Catalonia became part of the Hispanic Monarchy, experiencing a mix of prosperity and economic crises due to plagues and conflicts, with the economy recovering in the 18th century through American trade and the textile industry. The city, with nearly 100,000 inhabitants, did not grow beyond its walls, except for La Barceloneta expansion on the beach. Urban reforms were limited due to Barcelona's loss of capital status, but the sea wall was constructed in the 16th century with bastions like Llevant, Torre Nova, Sant Ramon, and Migdia.

During the 16th century, Barcelona underwent urban reforms, including the construction of a new sea wall with bastions such as Llevant, Torre Nova, Sant Ramon, and Migdia. Additionally, an artificial port was built to address the city's need for a proper mercantile center, as the previous port at the foot of Montjuïc was no longer suitable for the city's growing trade. Due to this, large ships had to unload goods using boats and rope ladders. The only significant urban reform in the city center was around the cathedral, where the Plaça de la Seu and Plaça de San Iu were constructed.

In the 15th century, Barcelona built a new port to accommodate larger trade ships, as the previous one could only handle boats due to its shallow depth. The construction process involved sinking a ship with stones as a foundation, followed by reinforcing and expanding the wall. By the end of the 16th century, the quay was 180 meters long and 12 meters wide. The port's development led to the embankment of the seafront between Pla de Palau and La Rambla, creating the Passeig del Mar, now known as Passeig de Colom.

During the 15th century, Barcelona expanded its port to accommodate larger trade ships, resulting in the creation of the Passeig del Mar, now Passeig de Colom. In the 16th century, the water supply and sewage system were upgraded, and a "master of the fountains" was appointed for maintenance. The city wall was further extended in the 17th century with new gates and infrastructure improvements, including paved streets, installed sewers, and built drinking water fountains. However, in the 18th century, the Principality of Catalonia and Barcelona lost much of their autonomy due to the Nueva Planta Decree, which replaced the Generalitat, the Corts, and the Consell de Cent with a military government, and reduced the municipal jurisdiction to the city, taking away its metropolitan area influence.

During the 15th to 18th centuries, Barcelona underwent significant changes, particularly in infrastructure and urban planning. The city's port was expanded, and the water supply and sewage system were upgraded. The city walls were extended, and new gates, paved streets, sewers, and drinking water fountains were added. However, the Principality of Catalonia and Barcelona lost much of their autonomy due to the Nueva Planta Decree in the 18th century.

During this time, Barcelona experienced a notable demographic increase and underwent industrialization, leading to the Industrial Revolution. The Bourbons initiated several military engineering projects, including the castle of Montjuïc and the fortress of the Citadel. The Citadel, built between 1715-1751, resulted in the demolition of 1200 houses in the Ribera neighborhood, leaving 4500 people homeless and without compensation. The Rec Comtal was also diverted during this time. Jorge Próspero de Verboom designed the Citadel as a pentagonal walled bastion with a protective moat and an esplanade of 120 m between the walls and surrounding buildings. The Citadel was later demolished in the Revolution of 1868 and replaced with the park of the Citadel.

Additionally, two new military roads were constructed, the Mataró road, which coincides with the current Pere IV street, and the Creu Coberta road, which connected with the Madrid road, currently the Hostafrancs and Sants streets. In 1753, the construction of the neighborhood of La Barceloneta began at the initiative of the Marquis of La Mina.

During the 15th to 18th centuries, Barcelona experienced significant infrastructure and urban planning developments, including the expansion of the port, upgrades to the water supply and sewage system, and the construction of new gates, paved streets, sewers, and drinking water fountains. The city walls were also extended, leading to the demolition of the Ribera neighborhood for the construction of the Citadel, which was later replaced with the park of the Citadel. The neighborhood of La Barceloneta was built on a small peninsula, with a grid layout designed by Pedro Martín Cermeño, and was the location of the city's first lighthouse. In 1771, the Edicto de obreria was approved, regulating private works and establishing the requirement of building permits and height limits for all buildings. This reflects the growing urbanization and industrialization of Barcelona during this time.

The Edicto de obreria, established in the late 18th century, introduced building permits, reports, and fees, and later set height limits for structures. Concurrently, private buildings transitioned from "artisan houses" to "multi-family houses," separating work and residence. Additionally, La Rambla, an ancient torrent turned urban area since the 16th century, underwent redevelopment between 1776 and 1778, involving the demolition of the inner wall, realignment of buildings, and creation of a French boulevard-style promenade. Although planned earlier, paseos of Sant Joan and Gràcia were constructed in the early 19th and late 1820s-1827, respectively. These developments highlight Barcelona's growing urbanization and industrialization.

During the late 18th and early 19th centuries, Barcelona experienced significant urbanization and industrialization. The Edicto de obreria introduced building regulations, leading to the construction of multi-family houses and height limits for structures. Notably, La Rambla was redeveloped between 1776 and 1778, and paseos of Sant Joan and Gràcia were built in the early 19th and late 1820s-1827, respectively. Additionally, new streets like the one named after Francisco González de Bassecourt, captain general of Catalonia, were laid out.

In terms of public spaces, the Born and Boqueria markets were established, and regulations for food products and coal marketing were implemented in 1752. Furthermore, the Paseo Nuevo or Paseo de la Explanada, adorned with ornamental fountains and lined with trees, was created next to the military Citadel, serving as the city's main green space until it disappeared during the urbanization works of the park of the Citadel.

During the 19th century, Barcelona underwent significant economic revitalization, particularly in the textile industry, which fueled a Catalan cultural renaissance. The Bonaplata Factory (1832) and La España Industrial (1849) were key establishments in this growth. The industrial era was marked by the demolition of city walls (1854-1859) and the implementation of the Eixample expansion project by Ildefons Cerdà. The Citadel was also demolished in 1868, making way for a public park. The textile industry faced a crisis in 1861 due to the American Civil War's cotton shortage, but the metallurgical industry thrived with the advent of railroads and steam navigation. The population expanded to 400,000 inhabitants by the end of the century, mainly due to immigration from other parts of Spain.

The 19th-century economic revitalization in Barcelona, driven by the textile industry's growth, faced a crisis in 1861 due to the American Civil War's cotton shortage. Simultaneously, the metallurgical industry flourished, spurred by railroads and steam navigation. Notable establishments include the Nueva Vulcano foundry (1836), La Barcelonesa (1841), and La Maquinista Terrestre y Marítima (1855). Industrialization led to significant urban planning changes in Barcelona to accommodate the labor and support services required by capitalist economic sectors.

The 19th-century economic boom in Barcelona, driven by the textile industry and boosted by the metallurgical industry, resulted in significant urban planning changes to accommodate the growing population and support services. This modernization was marked by three key factors: rural-to-urban migration, a strong connection between industrial and urban development, and improved infrastructure with an extensive road and rail network. Concurrently, municipal ordinances were established and reinforced, such as the Edicto de obrería (1814), the Pregón de policía urbana (1839), and the Bando general de buen gobierno, which regulated urban planning, sanitation, and building standards. The law of January 8, 1845, further defined the City Council's role in urban planning and public space management. These measures facilitated Barcelona's growth into a colonizing metropolis and set the stage for its modern infrastructure.

The first Municipal Ordinances were approved in 1856, consolidating and expanding previous regulations into a comprehensive urban code that governed civic and institutional relations. This code required building permits to include interior layout plans for the first time. However, these ordinances quickly became outdated due to the new Eixample plan, and in 1891, new ones were established to address the expansion's specificities and new connections. One significant urban planning action during this time was the opening of Calle de Fernando in 1827, which was later extended towards the Borne with the streets of Jaime I and Princesa.

The Pla de Palau expansion started in 1833, focusing on the city's core containing the Royal Palace, Llotja, and Aduana. The area underwent changes, including the Pla de Palau's enlargement and the construction of Portal de Mar in 1844-1848 by Josep Massanès. This grand entrance to Barceloneta from the old town was later demolished in 1859, along with the city walls. This expansion and renovation set the stage for better connections within the city.

The 1838 widening plan proposed by Massanès, which included the area of Plaça de Catalunya, was not fully realized. However, the confiscation of 1836 resulted in the construction and development of public spaces, such as La Boqueria and Santa Catalina markets, the Gran Teatro del Liceo (Liceu), and two squares by Francesc Daniel Molina: Plaça Reial and Plaça del Duc de Medinaceli. Additionally, new sanitary regulations caused the disappearance of parish cemeteries, and their plots were transformed into public squares, including Santa Maria, del Pi, Sant Josep Oriol, Sant Felip Neri, Sant Just, Sant Pere, and San Jaime (Sant Jaume). These urban planning efforts and changes contributed to the improved connectivity in the city during this period.

The confiscation of 1836 resulted in the creation of new public spaces, including the cemetery of the East or Pueblo Nuevo (Poblenou) in 1813-1819, followed by the Southwest or Montjuic cemetery in 1883 and the North or Collserola cemetery in 1969. The first gas lighting, a symbol of modernity, was introduced in 1842, with the formation of the Sociedad Catalana para el Alumbrado por Gas (Catalan Society for Gas Lighting), later renamed as Catalana de Gas y Electricidad. The new gas lighting illuminated streets such as La Rambla, Fernando Street, and Plaza de San Jaime. The Barcelona City Council and the Generalitat de Catalunya were located in Plaça de Sant Jaume, making it the political heart of the city.

In 1848, the first railroad line in peninsular Spain connected Barcelona to Mataró, marking a significant step in the city's growth as a metropolitan hub. This development led to the creation of stations like Francia (1854), Sants (1854), and Norte (1862), forming a railway network resembling a "Catalan eight." By the 1880s, Barcelona had established connections with France, Madrid, Zaragoza, and Valencia, as well as other Catalan provincial capitals. In 1856, gas was adopted for domestic stoves and heaters, and the Sociedad Catalana para el Alumbrado por Gas was renamed Catalana de Gas y Electricidad in 1856. These advancements contributed to Barcelona's emergence as a modern, interconnected city.

During the 1880s, Barcelona created links with France, Madrid, Zaragoza, and Valencia, as well as other Catalan provincial capitals. Two major rail companies, Ferrocarril del Norte and MZA (Madrid-Zaragoza-Alicante), were established and later merged into RENFE in 1941. Barcelona also developed its first fire and police services around this time. The Guardia Urbana de Barcelona was founded in 1843 to maintain public safety, and in 1849, the Sociedad de Socorro Mutuo contra Incendios emerged as a private firefighting company, which was replaced by the Sociedad de Extinción de Incendios y Salvamento de Barcelona in 1865, the city's first public fire department. Antoni Rovira i Trias served as its first chief, and the Casa de Comunes Depósitos was its first firehouse, followed by several more throughout the city. These advancements further solidified Barcelona's growth as a modern, interconnected city.

During the 1800s, Barcelona's fire department underwent significant changes, starting with the establishment of the Sociedad de Socorro Mutuo contra Incendios in 1849, led by architect Antoni Rovira i Trias, and housed in the Casa de Comunes Depósitos. The Land and Urban Planning Law of 1956, enacted to complement the Barcelona Provincial Planning Commission's Regional Plan of 1953, aimed to bring order to urban growth. It zoned Barcelona into three development areas: Levante, Poniente, and Diagonal Norte, and set aside land for infrastructure, facilities, and green spaces, including a proposed metropolitan park in the Collserola mountain range. However, many "partial plans" emerged from this initiative, often succumbing to landowners' pressures and leading to increased population density. Notable plans included the development of new neighborhoods, such as La Verneda and Besòs, along Diagonal Avenue's ends. Despite not being fully realized, the law significantly influenced Barcelona's urban development.

The Land and Urban Planning Law of 1956, which followed the Barcelona Provincial Planning Commission's Regional Plan of 1953, had a significant impact on Barcelona's urban development. The law divided the city into three development zones and designated areas for infrastructure, facilities, and green spaces. A notable feature was the plan for a metropolitan park in the Collserola mountain range. However, many "partial plans" emerged, often influenced by landowners, resulting in increased population density. Specifically, the areas at the ends of Diagonal Avenue saw significant development, with new neighborhoods like La Verneda and Besòs in the east and the expansion of Les Corts and Collblanc, as well as the projection of Zona Universitaria, in the west. This growth led to the construction of new markets to supply basic products in the corresponding years mentioned.

The years between 1968 and 1987 saw the emergence of several new neighborhoods in Barcelona, including Sant Gervasi, Carmel, Vall d'Hebrón, Port, Provençals, Lesseps, Trinitat, and Canyelles. This expansion led to a significant increase in automobile traffic, prompting improvements to the city's road network. Meridiana Avenue was opened, the First Ring Road (Ronda del Mig) was constructed, and plans were made for the Second Ring Road. Subway parking lots were built, and the freeway network was expanded due to the 1962 arterial network project, which included radial highways along the Vallès, Llobregat, and Maresme axes.

The period from 1968 to 1987 experienced the growth of Barcelona's neighborhoods, resulting in increased automobile traffic. To address this, the city improved its road network by constructing radial highways in the Vallès, Llobregat, and Maresme axes, as well as the First Ring Road. Plans were made for a Second Ring Road, and the freeway network was expanded. Three tunnels were proposed to cross the Collserola mountain range, but only the Vallvidrera tunnel's first phase and the Rovira tunnel were built. Public transportation shifted from streetcars to buses and the expansion of the metro network, with trolleybuses appearing in 1941 and disappearing in 1968.

From 1968 to 1987, Barcelona underwent urban development, leading to increased automobile traffic. The city improved its road network by building radial highways and tunnels, with only two of the three proposed tunnels completed. Public transportation transitioned from streetcars to buses and an expanded metro network, with trolleybuses appearing in 1941 and disappearing in 1968. In 1952, the city hosted the XXXV International Eucharistic Congress, which prompted the development of the Congreso (Congrés) neighborhood, featuring a housing complex designed by Josep Soteras, Carles Marquès, and Antoni Pineda. The complex, spanning 16.5 ha, included 3,000 homes, commercial spaces, a church, and various community services and facilities. Additionally, the city modernized its water, natural gas, electrical, and telephone networks during this period.

During Barcelona's urban development from 1968 to 1987, the city not only improved its road network and modernized infrastructure but also undertook various renovation projects across the city. These renovations included the creation of the avenues Príncipe de Asturias and Infanta Carlota, the installation of a monumental fountain at the intersection of Gran Via de les Corts Catalanes and Passeig de Gràcia, and the landscaping of Calvo Sotelo square, now Francesc Macià. The Paseo Marítimo's first section was also opened in 1957, an idea conceived in the 1920s but realized during this period, with a design by Enric Giralt i Ortet.

During Barcelona's urban development from 1968 to 1987, the city addressed its housing shortage by implementing the Social Urgency Plan of 1958, which resulted in the construction of large social housing blocks in peripheral neighborhoods like La Verneda, Torre Llobeta, La Trinitat, and Verdum. Additionally, the Zona Franca, an industrial sector initially planned as a free trade zone in 1900 by Fomento del Trabajo Nacional, was established between Montjuic mountain, the port, and the Llobregat. However, due to bureaucratic hurdles, unsuccessful projects, and the Civil War, its construction didn't start until the 1960s, ultimately developing as an industrial estate with nearby residential areas such as Casa Antúnez, Can Clos, La Vinya, and Polvorín. Concurrently, urban improvements included the creation of avenues Príncipe de Asturias and Infanta Carlota, the installation of a monumental fountain, and the landscaping of Calvo Sotelo square. The Paseo Marítimo's first section was also opened in 1957, designed by Enric Giralt i Ortet.

During Barcelona's urban development from 1968 to 1987, residential areas like Casa Antúnez, Can Clos, La Vinya, and Polvorín were part of the expanding industrial sector, including the establishment of Mercabarna in 1967 and the Zona d'Actividades Logísticas in 1993. The city's urban planning during this time was significantly influenced by Mayor Josep Maria de Porcioles (1957-1973), known as the "Porcioles era." The Municipal Charter of 1960 granted the City Council extensive powers in various areas, leading to the creation of the Municipal Housing Board and large housing estates such as Montbau (1958-1961), Southwest Besòs (1959-1960), and Canyelles (1974).

During Barcelona's urban development from 1968 to 1987, Mayor Josep Maria de Porcioles established the Municipal Housing Board, which oversaw the creation of large housing estates, including Montbau (1958-1961), Southwest Besòs (1959-1960), and Canyelles (1974). The period saw both beneficial urban actions, such as the covering of Aragón street, the extension of the Gran Vía, the adaptation of Montjuic's seafront, and the Barceloneta promenade, and negative consequences like increased real estate speculation. This led to popular discontent and the rise of "urban social movements" that combined frustration with urban decay and political opposition to the Franco regime.

During Barcelona's urban development from 1968 to 1987, the Municipal Housing Board, led by Mayor Josep Maria de Porcioles, constructed large housing estates, including Montbau, Southwest Besòs, and Canyelles. This period experienced both positive actions, such as infrastructure improvements, and negative consequences, like increased real estate speculation, which sparked public discontent and the emergence of "urban social movements." These movements protested urban decay and the Franco regime, opposing projects like the redesign of Lesseps square due to the First Ring Road (Ronda del Mig) and the Partial Plan of Vallbona, Torre Baró and Trinitat. There were also attempts at urban reorganization, such as the Master Plan for the Metropolitan Area of Barcelona (1966), aiming to balance profitability and urban construction, and the Plan Barcelona 2000 (1970), focusing on infrastructure while acknowledging the chaotic nature of urban growth.

The 1970s in Barcelona saw several urban development projects that didn't come to fruition, such as the Universal Exposition of 1982, which would have involved creating major avenues like a vertical axis linking Plaza de España with Vallès and a Gran Vía Norte. Also in 1970, the Vilalta Plan for wastewater treatment plant construction was approved. Between 1964 and 1972, the Plan de la Ribera was developed to urbanize the city's eastern seafront, but it had a lengthy administrative process and wasn't incorporated into the Regional Plan until 1970. This project, led by Antoni Bonet i Castellana, focused on deindustrializing the area and building a megastructure of luxury housing.

The Plan de la Ribera, proposed in the 1960s to urbanize Barcelona's eastern seafront and deindustrialize the area, underwent a redrafting request in 1972 due to opposition from locals and professionals. The project, led by Antoni Bonet i Castellana, was ultimately halted, but it is now seen as a push for urban renewal in line with international trends. Its coastal renovation concept was eventually realized during the Olympic Games. During the dictatorship, focus in green spaces was on maintaining and restoring existing areas, with Lluís Riudor leading Parks and Gardens in 1940.

In 1940, Lluís Riudor, a pioneer of landscaping in Catalonia, took over Parks and Gardens, focusing on maintaining and enhancing existing green spaces, such as Austria Garden in Park Güell, Monterols Park, Cervantes Park, and Montjuïc mountain projects to remove shantytowns. His successor, Joaquim Casamor, continued this work by creating thematic gardens like Mossèn Costa i Llobera and Mossèn Cinto Verdaguer. Post-dictatorship, with the arrival of democracy and the General Metropolitan Plan, Barcelona's urban and architectural landscape embraced international avant-garde trends. Riudor's and Casamor's focus on green spaces was a precursor to this shift.

The transition to democracy in the 1970s and 80s led to a shift in Barcelona's urban and architectural landscape, aligning it with international avant-garde trends. The new socialist administrations of Narcís Serra and Pasqual Maragall prioritized urban planning and architecture, implementing extensive urban reforms, including the acquisition of urban land due to industrial complexes relocating out of the city. This period saw an increase in public facilities like schools, parks, roads, and cultural and sports centers, culminating in the 1992 Olympic Games. Lluís Riudor and Joaquim Casamor's emphasis on green spaces served as a precursor to this transformation.

The new democratic government in the 1970s and 80s, led by Narcís Serra and Pasqual Maragall, transformed Barcelona's urban and architectural landscape to align with international trends. Oriol Bohigas was appointed as Urban Planning delegate, leading to increased public investment and a shift towards prioritizing local needs and public facilities. The city's focus moved from expansion to reconstruction, and from private to public initiative. The Plan for the reindustrialization of Barcelona's center led to the creation of an Urgent Reindustrialization Zone (ZUR), driving urban change and promoting the "monumentalization" of peripheral areas. This period culminated in the 1992 Olympic Games, establishing Barcelona's new international standing.

The democratic government in the 1970s and 80s, headed by Narcís Serra and Pasqual Maragall, implemented significant changes to Barcelona's urban and industrial landscape. Oriol Bohigas took on the role of Urban Planning delegate, resulting in increased public investment and a shift towards prioritizing local needs and facilities. The new industrial development was driven by a focus on research and technology, while urban planning was guided by the General Metropolitan Urban Development Plan (1976) by Joan Antoni Solans. This plan aimed to prevent speculation, rehabilitate degraded urban areas, and emphasize social, welfare, and cultural facilities. The Metropolitan Corporation of Barcelona was established, encompassing Barcelona and 26 neighboring municipalities. The urban transformation consisted of three main strategies: small-scale urban rehabilitation, urban restructuring (e.g., road reorganization and new central areas), and morphological reorganization, which resulted in the current administrative division of the city into ten districts.

The democratic government in the 1970s and 80s, led by Narcís Serra and Pasqual Maragall, implemented major changes to Barcelona's urban and industrial landscape, with Oriol Bohigas as Urban Planning delegate. A key tool for these interventions were the Special Plans of Interior Renovations (PERI), though their ambitious goals sparked numerous lawsuits, leaving the project largely ineffective by 1985. Despite this, the PERI's guidelines significantly influenced 20th-21st century urban planning. In the following years, the concept of "areas of new centrality" emerged, aiming to create a more polycentric and interconnected city by alleviating congestion in the center and revitalizing urban periphery sectors with intrinsic potential.

In the 1990s, Barcelona's democratic government, led by Narcís Serra and Pasqual Maragall with Oriol Bohigas as Urban Planning delegate, sought to decentralize the city and reduce congestion in the center by developing twelve "areas of new centrality." These areas, including RENFE-Meridiana, Diagonal-Sarrià, Tarragona street, Cerdà square, Port Vell, Glòries square, Diagonal-Prim (future Fòrum area), Sant Andreu-Sagrera, and four related to the Olympic Games: Montjuic, Diagonal-Zona Universitària, Vall'dHebron and Carles I-Avinguda Icària (future Olympic Village), were intended to revitalize urban periphery sectors with inherent potential. During this time, many city roads were upgraded, resulting in wide, often landscaped avenues primarily designed for pedestrian traffic, such as Avinguda de Gaudí, Avinguda de Josep Tarradellas, Carrer Tarragona, the connection between the old Rambles and the Rambla de Catalunya, Passeig de Lluís Companys, Avinguda de la Reina Maria Cristina, Via Júlia and Rambla de Prim. Although the "areas of new centrality" were not fully realized due to legal challenges, their guidelines significantly influenced 20th-21st century urban planning in Barcelona.

During Barcelona's urban development in the 1990s, under the leadership of Narcís Serra, Pasqual Maragall, and Oriol Bohigas, the city saw the creation of new centrality areas, pedestrian-friendly avenues, and revamped squares like Salvador Allende, Baixa de Sant Pere, Sant Agustí Vell, la Mercè, Sóller, and Robacols. Urbanization projects took place in sectors such as Ciutat Vella (Raval, Santa Caterina, Barceloneta), Carmel, Gràcia, Sarrià, Sant Andreu, and Poblenou. Affordable housing initiatives were promoted, and Eixample's interior courtyards were reclaimed as green spaces or public services. The 1988 Special Sewerage Plan of Barcelona (PECB) improved the coastal sewer network, reduced flood-prone areas, and enabled beach restoration through breakwater construction. These initiatives significantly shaped 20th-21st century urban planning in Barcelona, despite some incomplete projects due to legal challenges.

During Barcelona's urban development in the 1980s and 1990s, the city's leadership focused on enhancing green spaces and stormwater management. The 1997 Special Sewerage Plan for Barcelona (PECLAB) prioritized building stormwater regulation reservoirs to mitigate flooding. The advent of democracy facilitated the creation of new parks, which were often constructed on former municipal facilities, industrial areas, or railway facilities. Aesthetics, functionality, recreation, and services for specific groups, such as children and the elderly, were all essential considerations in these new green spaces. Examples include the Joan Miró park (1980-1982), Espanya Industrial park (1981-1985), Pegaso park (1982-1986), Clot park (1982-1986), Sant Martí park (1985), and Estació del Nord park (1988).

The Creueta del Coll park, built by the Martorell-Bohigas-Mackay team over an old quarry, is another example of Barcelona's focus on developing green spaces during the 1980s and 1990s. A significant transformation occurred in 1992 with the Olympic Games, which led to the remodeling of Montjuïc mountain's Olympic Ring, housing multiple sports facilities. Additionally, the Poblenou Olympic Village was constructed to accommodate athletes, designed by the Martorell-Bohigas-Mackay-Puigdomènech team.

The planning of the Olympic Village and surrounding areas involved several complex adaptations and installations, such as burying the coastal railroad, building sewage treatment plants, constructing a new port and beaches, laying out new transport axes, and installing facilities like the Telephone Exchange and Meteorology Center. Two significant skyscrapers, Hotel Arts and Torre Mapfre, were also built, altering Barcelona's skyline. Additionally, the Vall d'Hebron neighborhood was developed with a project that integrated green spaces and sports facilities.

The Olympic Village and surrounding areas underwent extensive development, including the construction of new infrastructure like sewage treatment plants, a port, beaches, and transportation axes. Two prominent skyscrapers, Hotel Arts and Torre Mapfre, were also built, significantly changing Barcelona's skyline. Furthermore, the Vall d'Hebron neighborhood was developed with a project that combined green spaces and sports facilities. In the context of the Olympics, the Old Port was renovated for leisure purposes, and new parks and gardens were created by various architects, such as the parks of Mirador del Migdia, Poblenou, Carles I, and the Cascades, Olympic Port, and Nova Icària, designed by Martorell-Bohigas-Mackay. Additionally, a Coastal Plan was implemented to restore the city's beaches, which had been eroded and were subsequently renovated for public use. The Olympic Press Village was constructed in this area between 1989-1991, designed by Carlos Ferrater.

In preparation for the Olympics, a Coastal Plan was executed to rejuvenate Barcelona's beaches, which had been severely eroded. The beaches, including Sant Sebastià, Barceloneta, Nova Icària, Bogatell, Mar Bella, and Nova Mar Bella, were cleaned, supplied with sand from the seabed, and opened to the public. Sewage treatment plants were established on the Besòs and Llobregat rivers, and underwater reefs were installed to promote marine life.

The Llobregat River was rerouted to extend the port, and the Raval neighborhood was revamped with the opening of the Rambla del Raval and the development of the Plaça dels Àngels cultural center, home to the Center of Contemporary Culture of Barcelona and the Museum of Contemporary Art of Barcelona. The Olympics also led to advancements in telecommunications with the construction of the Collserola and Montjuïc communications towers and the installation of 150 km of optical fiber cabling. Additionally, the city's road infrastructure was significantly expanded, particularly with the creation of ring roads encircling the urban perimeter.

The Olympics in 1992 prompted a comprehensive urban development plan in Barcelona, overseen by Josep Acebillo and Alfred Morales, which included the creation of three ring roads (Ronda de Dalt, Ronda del Mig, and Ronda del Litoral) to improve transportation. The Ronda del Mig, in particular, was a middle ring road that traversed the city under different names. Additionally, a campaign called "Barcelona posa't guapa" was initiated to restore and adapt facades, monuments, and dividing walls. The planning process was a significant challenge, but it served as an opportunity for strategic urban planning and modernization of the city.

The 1992 Olympics in Barcelona spurred a strategic urban planning strategy, led by Josep Emili Hernández-Cros from the city's Heritage department, that involved collaboration between social and economic agents. This effort led to a new city image, both locally and globally, and introduced the concept of the "Barcelona model" as a transferable urban reform project. As the century came to a close, there was a shift towards more sustainable urban planning, focusing on eco-friendly public spaces and community facilities, which were discussed at the 1998 Sustainable Barcelona Civic Forum.

The Sustainable Barcelona Civic Forum in 1998 established criteria for sustainable urban planning, emphasizing eco-friendly transportation and public spaces. A significant initiative was the promotion of bicycles as a primary mode of transport, with the installation of the first bicycle path in 1993 and the creation of a municipal bicycle rental company (Bicing) in 2007. Additionally, there was a growth in multi-municipal projects, focusing on infrastructure, transport, and delta rehabilitation. The Infrastructure Master Plan (PDI) led to an expansion and enhancement of public transportation, including a metro network, the return of the tramway, and improved bus services.

In the 21st century, Barcelona prioritized innovation, design, technology, and sustainability in urban planning. The Urban Strategies Advisory Council was established in 2000 to aid the City Council in making strategic decisions for the city and its surroundings, with a focus on integrating new technologies and preserving the industrial sector. A key project was the development of the 22@ district in 2000, which aimed to revitalize the declining industrial area of El Poblenou by transforming it into a hub for technology-driven companies, thereby maintaining the area's productive character.

In the 21st century, Barcelona prioritized innovation and technology in urban planning, leading to the establishment of the Urban Strategies Advisory Council and the creation of the 22@ district. The 22@ district, spanning 115 hectares, focused on revitalizing the industrial area of El Poblenou by attracting technology-driven companies, preserving its industrial character. A significant event, the 2004 Universal Forum of Cultures, drove additional urban changes, including the regeneration of the Poblenou neighborhood, the development of the Diagonal Mar neighborhood, and the creation of new parks, ultimately upgrading the city's leisure spaces.

In the 21st century, Barcelona's urban planning has focused on developing new centers, such as the Fòrum, 22@, and La Sagrera, while preserving the industrial character of areas like El Poblenou. The city has also prioritized improving communications, including the arrival of the high-speed train and the expansion of the port and El Prat airport. The metro network has been expanded with new and extended lines. The Plaça de les Glòries Catalanes is currently being remodeled to underground automobile traffic and recover land for public use. The 2004 Universal Forum of Cultures site, designed by Elías Torres and José Antonio Martínez Lapeña, features a 16-hectare multipurpose esplanade ending in a large photovoltaic panel, symbolizing the city's commitment to innovation and technology.

In the 21st century, Barcelona has enhanced its transportation system by extending metro lines (3, 5, 9, 10, and 11) and introducing a fully automated metro network. A bus rapid transit system was launched in 2012, and plans for a fourth ring road and Avinguda Diagonal streetcar connection are underway to improve metropolitan communications. Additionally, the city has installed pedestrian-friendly infrastructure, such as elevators and escalators, in areas like El Carmel, where subway extension work in 2005 led to the demolition of buildings and relocation of residents due to subsidence.

In response to the disruption caused by the metro extension in El Carmel in 2005, the Generalitat designated it as an AERI, allocating resources for public works, building rehabilitation, and public facility improvements. Regarding green spaces, Barcelona has developed several modern parks, such as the Central Park of Nou Barris (1997-2007) by Carme Fiol and Andreu Arriola, the Diagonal Mar Park (1999-2002) by Enric Miralles and Benedetta Tagliabue, and the Poblenou Center Park (2008) by Jean Nouvel. These parks showcase contemporary designs and provide residents with appealing recreational areas.

In 2015, an effort to update the urban planning strategy for the Metropolitan Area of Barcelona began, aiming for approval in 2021. This new plan, called the Pla Director Urbanístic (PDU), complements the 1976 General Metropolitan Plan and addresses the needs of the area's 36 municipalities and 3.5 million inhabitants. The PDU focuses on classifying land, setting building regulations, designating urban transformation areas, preserving the environment, and ensuring sustainable mobility. Ramon Torra, the manager of the Barcelona Metropolitan Area, highlights two main goals: developing a metropolitan urban planning model that is ecologically sustainable, economically efficient, and socially cohesive, and determining the methods and tools to implement it. Additionally, the first large dog park opened in 2016 in Nou Barris district, offering a 700 m² space with amenities for pets.

In 2016, a pilot project of "superblocks" was launched in the Poblenou area, limiting vehicle traffic and creating intermediate spaces for pedestrians, cyclists, and public transportation. The superblock in Poblenou restricts straight-line traffic, allowing vehicles to only turn at intersections and travel at 10 km/h. This has freed up interior block spaces for public use, with an ideas competition organized for architecture students to propose designs. Following this test, the Eixample district began implementing 42 new green axes and squares by 2030, with Consell de Cent street being the first to have four new public spaces created. This initiative is part of the broader urban planning strategy, PDU, focusing on sustainable development, efficient building regulations, and preserving the environment.

The first part of the urban planning strategy for Eixample, starting with Consell de Cent street, involves creating four new public spaces, or "agoras," at Rocafort, Borrell, Enric Granados, and Girona. The plan is to prioritize pedestrianization and sustainable transportation on one out of every three streets, with private vehicle access limited to residents and a speed limit of 10 km/h. This initiative aligns with the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) promoted by the United Nations. The COVID-19 pandemic has prompted urban planning changes in the city, some of which are temporary, while others may become permanent. A budget of 37.8 million euros has been allocated for these actions, with work set to begin in 2022.

In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, the Spanish government implemented a state of alarm, requiring citizens to stay at home and limiting vehicular traffic. To ensure social distancing, public spaces were repurposed for pedestrians and cyclists, using colored paint and temporary elements. These changes, promoted by the Urbanism councilor, exemplify tactical urbanism, with spaces for outdoor dining to reduce contagion risk.

The Urbanism councilor, Janet Sanz, introduced temporary measures to promote social distancing during the COVID-19 pandemic, classifying them as "tactical urbanism." These provisional modifications, including outdoor dining areas, have become permanent, as seen in the September 2021 ordinance regulating street furniture. This new regulation presents seven platform models to harmoniously incorporate hospitality establishment elements into the existing environment.
